title: Tuesday, 25th June 2019
bodyHTML:

(@3blackcrows: more in what sense? You mean post the news that the customer that bailed was Apple?)

So yeah, let's get on with it.

Of the big four, we think that:

· Sainsbury might be the most satisfied with its showing in this set of data because it recorded a mere –0.2% sales decline and a +5bps gain in market share (on a four week basis). This is the first time Sainsbury gained market share on a four week basis since December 2018. However, this growth appears to have been fueled by strong drinks sales.

· Morrison might be the least satisfied with its showing in this set of data. Its sales were down –3.1% (-20bps loss in market share) on a four week basis.

· Tesco sales fell by –0.6% but it gained+1bp of market share on a four week basis.

· ASDA sales declined –2.3% this month with a -20bps loss in market share on a four week basis.

Once again, Lidl and Aldi will likely take most satisfaction from these figures, but the discounters together recorded ‘merely’ +6.2% growth in sales (vs +7.5% last month) and +67bps gain in market share (vs +80 bps last month). We also note that M&S recorded a –2.2% sales decline on a 4 week Total Grocery basis with -10bps loss in market share (vs -5.2% growth and -17bp loss last month).

Noname @red not sure VV75 was suggesting Labour majority just opinion on the idea
Soundbuy Aldi and Lidl...........no stopping them.........
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good move by Hunt: £15Bn additional spend on defence. Will it please Dad's Army enough for them to vote him in though?
Bluesky21 My local Sainsbury now seem to be running permanent promotions of hard liquor like Jack Daniels ...
BE11:18am

It is, as I say, weather. Ice cream sales £15m lower than this time last year. Beer down £17m and burgers down £6m,.

Shinshin @VV75 He'll have to be quick, most firms will decamp voluntarily to friendlier places if he gets in to no. 11
AS2 :)

red are lidl doing online in uk yet?
Noname @red I don't think any conversations around the future well being of the environment are a waste of time :)
11:19 am
BE11:20am

Clive Black at Shore takes a long walk through it all.

red @Nonameu misunderstand. its highly unlikely to happen hence not worth worrying about. if i believe labour will get in, i'll let u know about it. im usually right. mostly. which helps ;)
Bluesky21 If you catch Dave Lewis in an investor meeting, he will tell you that he does not run the business on like-for-like sales figures
BE11:20am

We have spelt out for some years that we are not addicted to the monthly market share data issued by Kantar and Nielsen, not least because it can miss a beat and with wholesale activity increasingly featuring within the business models of the UK supermarkets there are perhaps more gaps in reports as a measure of what Tesco's^ (TSCO, Buy) CEO, Dave Lewis, calls the ‘quantum of sales’. Where we do see value in their output, however, is in the trend revealed by such regular data. Hence, we rarely become too excited by a particularly positive or negative score, but we are alive to notable wider peaks and troughs

cracklenpop @red farage and tories are 'the nutters'
BE11:21am

In this respect the June 2019 update is a concern noting 0.4% four-week (4W) sales growth according to Nielsen (Kantar suggest 1.4% in the 12W to the 16th June, implying a flat 4W market), suggesting negative underlying volumes, and, more pointedly the comment: "‘It’s clear that promotions, events and the vagaries of the weather have a big impact on
supermarket sales. The summer trading season stretches 18 weeks from the first May bank holiday to the last week in August. In the first seven weeks of summer 2010, shoppers have so far spent £350m less in supermarkets. This equates to a 2.1% fall in value sales compared to the same period last year. This means that for supermarkets to match the same level of sales as last summer, shoppers would now need to spend £26bn during the remaining 11 weeks. This looks a tall order as weekly growth is currently down, and we would need a sustained heatwave through to August, as we had last summer, just for the growth at supermarkets to stand still’.

Bluesky21 A focus on topline is really not constructive unless you are doing short-term trading ... which I suppose most of the buy side now does
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian They will just list somewhere else. The guy is an idiot.
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Skipping .... quite a lot ......

red @cracklenpopits all relative. if you put labour into the mix, u shift the lines
BE11:22am

We are not inclined to adjust our financial expectations on the supermarkets just yet, but it would be incorrect to say that we are totally relaxed about the current trading environment for the quoted UK supermarkets and so the robustness of our FY2020 estimates. Therefore, we will continue to monitor the secondary data and take a view on our current forecasts in due course but at this juncture the risk to nudges down feels higher than was the case in the spring. Within such a context, sentiment towards the UK supermarkets has already responded to the weakening trading data and is unlikely to more positively adjust until there is evidence of stabilisation and improvement. Over the summer months, as Nielsen point out, it is difficult to see this happening, which is likely to mean that short-term sector performance will remain muted. That said the comparatives in H2 CY2019 progressively improve and there are absolute and relative moving parts that make this increasingly defensive sector where free cash generation is much more robust, more resilient; so, come the end of October, if there is more extreme tension around the UK-EU relations then the supermarkets may appear somewhat stronger and more stable than other more cyclical domestic sectors.

PBateman what bookies are being covered today?
cracklenpop @redAgree - the Tories have no monopoly on nutters either.
nightingale20201 TSCO & Sains are talking new initiatives/.. - Tesco Premium , Sainsbury - https://www.google.com/url?client=internal-uds-cse&cx=007466294097402385199:m2ealvuxh1i&q=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2019/jun/23/sainsburys-salmon-skin-crisps-to-kombucha-edgy-new-range&sa=U&ved=2ahUKEwi64JLTtITjAhUBKBoKHb0uCMsQFjABegQIAxAC&usg=AOvVaw0GzI4jQD9Kb5cJagTPOfPT
Grouchmonkey How much of the Didldidi growth is new store openings? Do you have any figures on a ales/sq ft basis?
BE11:23am

As such our OVERWEIGHT sector recommendation can be expected to be pressurised in the near-term but we firmly believe that Morrisons and Tesco, the latter following an effective recent Capital Markets Day, offer the prospect of robust ongoing free cash, earnings and dividend growth. With respect to Sainsbury’s, where we repeat relief at the current Nielsen score, we remain nervous about the need for a profit reset in order to compete more effectively, notably at the operating level, plus we are concerned about the contraction in underlying profitability, stripping back cash exceptional items. Hence, until we are clear about the ongoing earnings and free cash flow streams we are likely to remain cautious; maybe the September Capital Markets Day will lead to a refreshed view? As for M&S, well it remains in transformation mode, reiterating the ongoing store closure programme with much work underway across the business. We will be introducing new post-Rights Issue financial forecasts shortly following its acquisition of 50% of Ocado Retail.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Far right are nutters/far left are nutters. Vote Hunt and avoid both!
Grouchmonkey Sorry sales, not ales. Though could be...

Pharma On a random tangent, which retail-friendly brokers allow you to deal with Swiss shares. The one I use limits you to EU and US, so things like Nestle have to be bought/solf via the German listing. Won't be possible from next week.

One mechanism I have proposed is to legislate so that any company listed in London is required to contribute to tackling the climate change crisis and if it fails it should be delisted.

This means that when we de-list companies that fail to meet environmental criteria from the London Stock Exchange, investors can be confident that their money is not going on making the world uninhabitable for their children.

MonkeyTrader DJ AbbVie Nears Deal to Buy Allergan for More Than $60 Billion -- Sources
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian They list abroad. Our soft-power to influence diminishes. The same sort of moronic thinking that eminates out of the Abbott camp wrt arm sales to Saudi.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

(@PerhapsNotMyRealNameThisTime: how long's an hour to you? To me, it's about an hour.)

BE11:30am

There was a Citi note spelling it out yesterday.

BE11:31am

Drax shares are down c.30% over the last 5 months as it rekindles its’ relationship with the forward power and gas prices. The problem is, European gas price in the short term is expected to face further downside pressure, potentially dragging down forward power prices in the UK. With no reason to turn more constructive given the commodity price outlook, limited visibility on capacity market payments this year and an expected weak 1H results, we reiterate our Sell and lower our PT to 265p.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

ommodity price back in the driving seat.

Following recent weakness of Drax shares, it has now re-established its relationship with the UK forward power and gas prices. We see no reason why this relationship should not continue going forwards.

Weak gas (and power) prices outlook.

As Citi Commodity team highlight here, Europe has already seen a doubling of LNG imports which have flooded the market and we expect further LNG to head our way. With the prospect of gas storage already full by late summer (2 months earlier), we see downside risk to 2019 gas prices. While this is likely to be most visible to short dated curve, it’s likely to cap longer dated forward curves or even for them to be dragged lower. Given commodity prices’ linkage to Drax shares, we see potential downside risk from here.

Capacity market remains uncertain.

The European Commission now has all the necessary information for its capacity market investigation. There is no specific deadline for a decision to be made, although BEIS is still hopeful that a decision will come before end of 2019. Given the duration of previous investigations, we see risk of no capacity payment in 2019.

Weak 1H, leaving 2H exposed to downgrade.

We expect 1H results to deliver 39% of FY EBITDA (CITIe is 15% lower than consensus), which is c.4% of FY EPS, given lower production across its fleet. This leaves Drax exposed on its FY EBITDA consensus of £400-410m, in our view. We have updated our forecast and valuation to reflect the latest lower commodity price outlook, with near term EPS broadly unchanged due to hedging. Our 12m PT is now lower at 265p. We also open a downside catalyst watch on the expected weak 1H results.

PerhapsNotMyRealNameThisTime BE i am just the voice in your head, reminding you that we are almost half way through the best hour of the day.
red @nightingale20201lidl here is actually slightly upper range, not really a discounter. strange but true.

Breaking news ABBVIE NEARS A DEAL TO BUY ALLERGAN FOR MORE THAN $60B

AbbVie Inc. is nearing a deal to buy Allergan PLC for more than $60 billion, according to people familiar with the matter, as the two big drugmakers bet a combination will deliver new sources of growth they have struggled to find on their own.

The takeover, worth $188 a share in cash and stock, is expected to be announced later Tuesday, the people said. The price, mainly to be paid in cash, represents a 45% premium over Allergan’s closing share price Monday of $129.57.

cracklenpop @Mouseletthey're all about enhancing the prospects of greater drug discovery, no?

Allergan has come around as a rumour so often in recent years, I'm struggling to locate my most recent notes on it .... One moment .....

Excel Developer @nightingale20201: nice, cornettos are cheap at Sainsbury's I see.
Pharma @Mouslet, hear hear. We are fast approaching the singularity, where there is only one Pharma company, and the only R&D it is doing is immuno-oncology.
nichoman why is it never my pharma dogs that get bought ??
11:36 am
BE11:37am

Okay, so it's a takeover as opposed to the split that management have talked about without really doing anything concrete ....

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Generally the pharma industry is doomed. Continual higher barriers to commercialisation are reducing returns to lower than weighted cost of capital. The take home is you need to choose pharma stocks very very carefully. A sector tracker will go nowhere IMO.
Pharma @nichoman - have you tried Korea? Their testing rules aren't as strict.
VV75 that is quite the premium for such a big stock
BE11:37am

Here's Cowen from a day or two ago.

Excel Developer #ClimateChange: can't we just plant trees on all the moorlands as a carbon sink?
BE11:38am

We continue to believe that Allergan appears to have a meaningful amount of trapped value, but clearly that has not been the prevailing view of investors. Although recent execution has been solid and the cash generation healthy, the frustration with the R&D productivity and capital allocation decisions linger.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

[T]he advantage of a split, (instead of what management was attempting to previously accomplish with sales of its individual non-core assets), would be the ability and simplicity to package the entire set of those assets into one entity instead of attempting to find individual buyers. This would allow for a more controlled process. However, this would
also require separating all common functions, and creating an entirely new company for the residual assets ("ResidualCo") that would need new management. This would clearly not be trivial. There would need to be a period to report separately and there could be very modest tax leakage, as well as likely increased spending of $50-100MM for this new entity.
But it is our understanding that there are no regulatory or tax reasons why Allergan could not pursue this. And as we stress above, it would be easier to control the process than individual divisional sales.

BE11:39am

Trade sale certainly simplifies the process, and while it's a big premium it's also a beaten down valuation.

BE11:40am

{I]f we are correct in our current modeling, and accounting for all the major exclusivity losses, we believe 2019 will be the base year that should allow investors to look forward to what we believe is a solid growth story at a discounted value. Specifically, at the price as of this publishing of $130, the shares are currently trading at 8.5x 2020 EBITDA with a current 2.8x net debt leverage ratio, which should exit 2021 at less than 2.0x. And we believe the company would be completely delevered by H2:2022. And finally, the current earnings multiples are 7.5x 2020, and 7.0x 2021.

FATDAZ Re future drugs/ pharmas etc how long before the design of new drugs can be undertaken completely in a computer model or is that just a fantasy??
11:41 am
BE11:41am

... which reflects the Botox price competition, a pipeline that's delivered not much and I think some opiate exposure right?

BE11:41am

Anyway, we'll come back to it.

undefined
Mouselet Trees are a dreadful carbon sink, because they rot and the carbon comes out again, and cutting down trees and sinking them in anoxic parts of the ocean isn't really on offer
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Okay, what was on the list earlier?

Plato the Cook a lot of drug discovery is just throwing stuff (in varying combinations) against a wall to see what sticks.
CS1 @FAT: isn't that where AI comes in ?
Mouselet fatdaz: complete fantasy - we can't model protein folding, we particularly can't model how a protein refolds around a putative drug molecule, and we particularly particularly can't model how the putative drug interacts with the other myriad proteins in the person
BE11:43am

Bookmakers? K. Mostly down apart from William Hill.

Pharma @FATDAZ, I'd say fantasy. Most drug R&D is still empirical, in the sense that you carefully design a series of compounds based on decades of experience, and then throw them in the assays to see which one(s) actually work.
Excel Developer @Mouselet: that doesn't square with all the howls of protest about the Brazilian rain forests being chopped down. Either forests are good or they are bad, surely?
William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 151.10, up 5.9 (+4.06%), High: 153.25, Low: 144.85, Volume: 1.55m

PerhapsNotMyRealNameThisTime Hill up on Eldorado deal?
1966AndAllThat IMHO Pharmacy will always be attractive. It promises the chance of longer life for us and our loved ones. Something that will always attract money (and charlatans)
11:44 am
BE11:44am

.... which is after it confirmed that the Eldorado proposed takeover of Caesars in the States would expand its JV with the former.

Mouselet Forests are good at producing oxygen, and forests in a steady state produce a reasonable amount of oxygen. But if you want net carbon capture steady-state forests are not the thing.
Mouselet [pretty much by definition of 'net']
FATDAZ @Pharma thank you
BE11:45am

Here's Goodbody to talk us through the benefits.

BE11:45am

William Hill has this morning confirmed in a press release that under the terms of its strategic partnership with Eldorado Resorts, it has the exclusive right to operate sports books at all properties owned or managed by Eldorado in the US and to operate mobile sports betting in states where Eldorado obtains a licence. These rights also apply to any acquisitions that Eldorado completes and therefore should the Caesars deal complete it will gain access to its proprieties for sports betting.

As we outlined yesterday Caesars operates 35 casinos in 14 states and 7 of these states either have legal sports betting or have passed legislation to allow it. Including its 13 properties in Nevada, Caesars operates 25 casinos in states that have or will soon have legalised sports betting. The 5 additional states that Caesars brings to this merger are California, Arizona, North Carolina, Kentucky and Maryland. The 18 states the combined group would operate in would cover c.50% of the US population.

While limited detail is provided in this release, we would note that it appears that William Hill will be able to operate more Retail sportsbooks in the US should the Caesars/Eldorado deal complete. In addition, the combined group increases its potential market access to 5 states it did not currently have market access. Although these 5 states (California, Arizona, North Carolina, Kentucky and Maryland) have not passed sports betting legislation, this is a positive to have in the background. There are a number of questions we have such as (i) will William Hill US get access to run/supply sports books at Caesars 13 Las Vegas properties and if so when?; (ii) will William Hill US get any access to the Caesars brand for sports betting purposes; (iii) will WMH US get access to Caesars deal with EPSN; and (iv) what are Eldorado’s plans regarding use of the Caesars brand for sports and how does this interact with use of the William Hill brand. Overall, given the weakness in William Hill’s share price as of late this news should be well received as it has the potential to significantly increase the US optionality of its business.

Mouselet The Brazilian rain forest is interesting as habitat and I believe it produces useful local climate effects, but it's not very relevant in the total carbon accounting, unless you're cutting it down and burning it
Excel Developer @Mouselet: when a tree produces oxygen, does it not strip the oxygen molecule from one of the two in the C02 compound?
Mouselet Yes, and the carbon goes into enlarging the tree, and most of the carbon gets released when some other tree falls down and rots
11:45 am
BE11:46am

Or, briefer, Morgan Stanley.

BE11:46am

Eldorado's agreed merger with Caesars makes William Hill's position for US sports betting more powerful, with wider market access, boosted revenues and potential optionality on brand, database and media assets. With US sports worth 35-55% of the current market cap, we would buy the shares here.

Mouselet So growing fast-growing trees and then throwing them into the middle of the Black Sea is a semi-plausible carbon sink. But a mature forest isn't.
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE how can Drax track power prices with a CFD agreement from UK Gov/UK Taxpayers essentially guaranteeing returns. Perhaps I'm missing something, I'd not hold DRX because I don't believe in Welfare accounting.
Excel Developer @Mouselet: not released as carbon gas though. Sits on the ground and given millions of years becomes oil, no?
Mouselet fallen trees stopped sitting on the ground and turning into coal roughly when the termite was invented
cracklenpop Billy Hill getting deeper into the US - what could possibly go wrong?
GBKrona @BE - any comments on Petrofac, please?
Potter Anyone have any insight on what's going on with ASOS?
CS1 @Mouse@ I'd worry more about the perma-frost melt, which is not included in warming models.
Brogue Trader Altran / CapGem?
BE11:48am

So Caesars agreement with the Oneida tribe (yeah, never forget America's weird) gives it access to New York, which is the trophy state here ....

11:48 am
BE11:49am

More widely, we think the combination of first skin access across all ERI states, as well the capability to add more states as a by-product of its strong retail offer (Eldorado is exclusive to William Hill, William Hill is not exclusive to Eldorado), means William Hill now has the best market access agreements of any operator in our coverage.Retail operations. William Hill's Eldorado agreement also gives it exclusivity to run the group's landbased sportsbooks, and we expect this will also roll over to the new Caesars properties. While we do not know the economic agreement this might entail, we expect it will be on the same terms as ERI (share of capex investment, share of profit), and assuming sports represents ~2% of casino revenue, in-line with market average, would imply Caesars casino sportsbooks could generate $100m of revenue if rolled out to every property.Caesars Online. Caesars currently has an agreement with Scientific Games to provide its technology and pricing. Given William Hill is migrating its US operations onto its new technology stack in the next two months, we could theoretically see the logic for ERI to realise synergies by moving the supply of Caesars' online sports betting operation from Scientific Games to William Hill. Should such a scenario play out, it would create a third major brand in the US market from which William Hill would generate revenue (William Hill also receives a cut of TSG/FOX Bet revenue in states in which it uses an Eldorado skin).

BE11:49am

Etc.

Dec69 - Skeptic @Potter the over-expectation of performance by ASOS is now in a mindsight of underachievement. Look at cash/net debt and changes in the business model and general consumer spending. online isn't immune.

Wider sector running back on what appear to be a cocktail of regulatory concerns .....

FATDAZ re climate change have the activists/ researchers looked at the impact of a move to EVs over the next three decades to balance a reduction in vehicle emissions vs the extended load on generating capacity which I doubt can be entirely picked up by renewables

- Provides immediate scale and profitability to AbbVie's growth platform, excluding Humira, significantly expanding and diversifying its revenue base with new therapeutic areas, including Allergan's leading medical aesthetics business

- Combined company will produce robust cash flow to support continued dividend growth, further investment in the pipeline and reduction of debt levels
- Transaction delivers significant and immediate accretion and provides an attractive return on invested capital
- Creates substantial value for shareholders of both companies and is expected to close in early 2020
- Allergan Shareholders will receive 0.8660 AbbVie Shares and $120.30 in cash for each Allergan Share, for a total consideration of $188.24 per Allergan Share
- Transaction equity value of approximately $63 billion

New evidence suggests topline growth could be underpinned by improving customer acquisition but the cost of acquisition continues to rise as higher promotions are still being used as a recruitment tool. We are also taking a less positive view on the US as data suggests ASOS is (unexpectedly) significantly repositioning price in this market via higher promotions. BE11:57am

We downgrade to Neutral, lower our PT to £33 and transfer coverage. Despite our above cons. expectations for FY19 sales growth, we are more cautious on the level of margin investment required to drive this growth. Over the past 6m, changes to pricing, promotions and newness have significantly impacted ASOS's topline and margins. In this note, we analyse how these are changing across 8 markets using UBS Evidence Lab data. Improving customer acquisition through higher 'newness' and more competitive pricing supports our above cons. FY19 topline forecast (UBSe ~17%, cons. ~16%) but the cost of growth doesn’t seem to be easing. UBS Evidence Lab data suggests ASOS is investing more margin than previously expected to reaccelerate: 1) customer acquisition and 2) growth in the US. Reflecting this, we are now c.20bps below margin guidance for FY19.

Excel Developer @daz: hehe
BE11:58am

We were expecting to see higher promotions in EU markets as ASOS tries to restore active customer growth, but instead we saw EU post-promotion prices -9% vs -12% at the group level. The main driver of this difference is the US, where the data suggests a major price repositioning after the US distribution centre (DC) went live in February. Post-promotion prices in the US are down 22% in P3 so far. There are not enough data points yet to conclude whether this reflects weakness in the US, offer or simply a new strategy that better caters to US customers and could support higher market share.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Petrofac’s E&C business continues to deliver projects and grow its top line - FY19 revenue is expected to be around ~$4.5bn (up from ~$4.1bn at FY18), in line with management’s guidance but slightly below our expectation (~$4.6bn), with margins also expected to be at the low end of previous guidance. The EPS business has seen a growth in project work, which has offset the lower operations activity, but also expected to be in line with expectations.

Petrofac expects to end H1/19 with $0.1bn of net debt, reflecting the reversal in working-capital movements seen at FY18, tax and dividend payments made in the period, and in line with management’s previous guidance. Non-core asset sales are ongoing.

BE12:03pm

Petrofac’s backlog at the end of H1/19 was $8.9bn, down from $9.6bn at FY18. This reflects the company’s recent challenges in Saudi Arabia and Iraq, as well as some awards taking slightly longer than anticipated due to the ongoing challenging macro outlook. The company has a busy tendering pipeline of ~$15bn of bid opportunities due for award in H2/19 (this was ~$32bn at the start of the year).
